fields.headline: World Cup diary
fields.bodyText: Since glitzy new stadiums are two a penny, host cities have had to be inventive to stand out from the crowd. None more so than Suwon, just south of Seoul, which has carved a niche for itself with some unique sanitation facilities. Lavatories that have been designated Beautiful Toilets are even marked on the map ahead of major landmarks. Obviously a man with a clear idea of where the seat of affections truly rests, the mayor's belief was that "if tourists feel comfortable in the toilet they will want to come back to Korea". · England's draw with Nigeria was so dull that fans found alternative entertainment by watching one of the stewards fall asleep on his feet before falling over. Now there's a job Emile Heskey could do. · The World Cup, as we all know, can make it tricky to concentrate on what you are meant to be doing during the day. So it is not surprising to learn that crime has dropped dramatically in South Korea since the start of the tournament. Murderers have apparently been most distracted with a 67% reduction in homicides. Great to know that the World Cup is bringing football to the ordinary people. · Never mind the perilous business of trying to back a favourite in this turbulent market. Shrewd punters know the bet to be on is Victor Chandler's offer of 4-1 that Don't Cry For Me Argentina is re-released. Who cares if it doesn't pay out, just think of the emotional satisfaction. · Japanese fans brought the country's largest mobile phone company to a halt this week when 100 million callers tried to buy the 750 tickets that had been made available for Japan's game against Russia. A spokesperson for NTT DoCoMo blamed full-throttle use of the automatic redial button and announced that a recorded "sold out" message will greet callers looking to buy tickets for today's encounter between Japan and Tunisia, which should calm things down no end.
